document.masterDocTitle: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Limosina fulva
Malloch, 1912: 4
( holotype ♀ , USNM, examined).

Leptocera fulva
.—
Roháček et al ., 2001: 154
(World catalog).

Limosina scutellaris
Williston, 1896: 432
( lectotype ♀ , present designation by M. Buck , BMNH), a primary junior homonym of
Limosina scutellaris Haliday, 1836
.

Limosina discalis Malloch, 1912: 8
(replacement name for
Limosina scutellaris Williston, 1896
).—Buck in
Roháček et al ., 2001: 23
, 154 (synonymy).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description . Male terminalia ( Figs. 239–242 ): Sternite 5 with 15–20 large scales on hind margin. Epandrium expanded dorsally (posterior view). Anterior section of surstylus with angulate and well sclerotized anterolateral corner (ventral view). Anterior process of surstylus wide. Posterior section of surstylus medium to dark brown, long, dilated apically; with long, medial bristle removed from apex; this bristle very long and curved ventrally at wide arc; apex with a series of three short, stout, more or less blunt spines flanked by 1(–2) hair(s) on each side. Cercus elongate, simple; basal 3/4 stout, with a series of ca. four hairs distally; apical part slender and bare; apex truncate and slightly produced posteriorly. Aedeagal complex as in Figs. 269–272 .

Type material .
Limosina fulva Malloch.
Holotype ♀ ( USNM ): PANAMA , Prov. Colón , Canal Zone , Tabernilla ,
27.iv.1907
, A. Busck. Paratype ♂ ( USNM ): same data as holotype but
6.ii.1911
. Note: the other 8 ♂♂ paratypes are misidentified
Leptocera dicrofulva
sp.n. (see above).

Limosina scutellaris Williston
(=
L. discalis Malloch
). Lectotype ♀ (designated here by M. Buck ) and 3 ♀♀ paralectotypes ( BMNH ): SAINT VINCENT , windward side, H.H. Smith.

Other material examined .

Distribution . Widespread and generally common in the Neotropical region. From southern Florida (Broward Co., Map 1) and northern Mexico ( Tamaulipas ) to Bolivia , Paraguay and southern Brazil (Santa Catarina). In Ecuador known from both sides of the Andes. Curran (1934) also mentions the species (as
L. discalis
) from St. Charles I. [= Floreana] on Galápagos . We have examined numerous
Leptocera
from this and five other Galápagos islands (see under
L. erythrocera
) but cannot confirm its occurrence there. Widespread on Caribbean Islands ( Cuba , Jamaica , Dominican Republic , Puerto Rico , Guadeloupe, Dominica , Saint Vincent , Grenada , Trinidad and Tobago ). Most common in lowlands but occasionally up to 2,100 m . One record from 3,200 m (Cerro de la Muerte, Costa Rica ) appears suspicious.

Discussion . This species and the much rarer
L. prolixofulva
sp.n. are the only species in the
L. fulva
group with a series of three stout spines at the apex of the posterior section of the surstylus and a relatively narrow posteromedian process of female sternite 7. The distinguishing characters between these two species are discussed under
L. prolixofulva
sp.n.
Leptocera fulva
is somewhat variable with regard to the shape of the posterior section of the surstylus. In some South American specimens its apical portion is less dilated and the apical spines are more slender and have finer tips. However, there seems to be no morphological gap between the two forms, which probably merely represent extreme states of individual variation.
